awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Confining Magnetism to Two-Dimensions in Transition Metal Oxide Atomic Layers
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: As the dimensions of materials in modern devices approach thicknesses close to a few atomic layers, small deviations in atomic arrangements can occur leading to electronic and magnetic properties which differ vastly from the properties of the bulk materials. Using advanced synthesis tools which permit the combination of atomic layers of materials with different compositions, the atomic deviations can be effectively manipulated to produce novel effects. In this project, high-intensity X-rays are used to image the atomic-scale structure of the interfaces of layers of thin crystalline oxide films. The information gained from imaging these materials is required to help scientists and engineers understand why some oxide materials lose their useful magnetic properties when their thicknesses are reduced to a few atomic layers. The X-ray results are combined with high-resolution electron microscopy, magnetic and transport measurements, and theoretical calculations to design specific combinations of oxide materials to achieve magnetism in single layers of oxide materials. This project has exciting implications for the design of novel materials and devices for information processing, quantum computing and low-powered sensors. This project provides a highly collaborative environment and access to advanced technical resources for training undergraduate and graduate students in the development of the next generation of advanced nanoscale materials. The project provides low-cost tools for visualizing abstract concepts related to crystallography to foster the public understanding of the development of new technologically-relevant crystalline materials.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project uses state-of-the-art synchrotron X-ray facilities at the Argonne National Laboratory and the Berkeley National Laboratory to carry out three-dimensional non-destructive atomic-scale mapping of the atomic, electronic and magnetic structures of magnetic perovskite oxide surfaces and interfaces. This research provides a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental interactions which occur at the interfaces between atomically-thin magnetic oxide films and other polar and non-polar perovskite materials and establishes a link between the observed interactions and the physical properties of these systems. A combination of first principles theory, high-resolution electron microscopy and temperature-dependent magnetic, transport and element-specific synchrotron X-ray magnetic dichroism measurements is used to design novel oxide heterointerfaces for achieving the confinement of ferromagnetism in two-dimensional oxide layers. These materials have applications in novel spin-based electronic devices. The wide range of cutting-edge research tools utilized in this activity are used to enhance the education of undergraduate and graduate students to prepare them for careers in scientific research and materials and device engineering. An important component of this project is the development of low-cost augmented reality tools for visualizing complex atomic and electronic structures for classroom instruction and public outreach to K-12 schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Advancements in the field of quantum materials have opened up exciting possibilities for the development of next-generation energy-efficient devices. A key area of interest lies in understanding and controlling electronic, magnetic, and structural interactions at interfaces between atomically-thin quantum materials. This research has significant implications for stabilizing novel properties that can revolutionize various technological applications.

To achieve these objectives, a multidisciplinary approach combining various synthesis techniques with atomic-scale control, synchrotron-based X-ray spectroscopy, diffraction-based imaging, and high-resolution electron microscopy has been employed. This comprehensive methodology has yielded remarkable results in several key areas.

Firstly, the research has successfully established a clear link between structural distortions at polar interfaces and thickness-dependent magnetic transitions in the colossal magnetoresistive material LaSrMnO3. This understanding of the relationship between structure and magnetism paves the way for the design and development of new functional materials with tailored magnetic properties.

Secondly, the team has demonstrated how electrostatic boundary conditions can be tuned in multilayer structures to stabilize ferromagnetism in atomically-thin oxide films. This breakthrough is crucial for creating stable and controllable ferromagnetic systems, which are highly desirable for various electronic and spintronic applications.

Thirdly, the researchers have showcased the formation of high-mobility electronic conductivity and superconductivity at interfaces between insulating magnetic polar oxides and non-polar oxides like SrTiO3 and KTaO3. This discovery holds immense promise for the advancement of quantum computing, information storage, and energy storage technologies.

The broader impacts of these results are far-reaching, extending to the development of quantum materials for computation, information storage and processing, sensors, and energy storage. The ability to probe atomic-scale structural distortions at interfaces and correlate them with macroscopic electronic and magnetic properties is a critical advancement in the fields of physics and engineering.

The research project has also been dedicated to training the next generation of scientists and engineers. Undergraduate and graduate students at North Carolina State University and have been provided with cutting-edge training in synthesis and characterization tools on campus and at national synchrotron facilities including the Advanced Photon Source  (APS) at Argonne National Laboratory and the Advanced Light Source (ALS) at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. Moreover, the project has actively focused on recruiting and mentoring students from diverse backgrounds, promoting inclusivity and diversity in STEM fields.

The outcomes have been highly successful in fostering academic growth and career opportunities for students. The project has resulted in the awarding of four doctoral degrees, with an impressive 50% being female students. Additionally, undergraduate students have been actively engaged in the research project through summer research opportunities and the Physics Undergraduate Senior Design Course at NC-State University. This hands-on experience has led to the involvement of six undergraduate students, 50% of whom are from underrepresented minority groups. Many of these students have continued their journey in STEM fields, pursuing graduate degrees or careers in industry, motivated by their enriching research experience.

To enhance outreach activities and aid the visualization of complex crystal structures, the project has developed modules that utilize a low-cost virtual reality toolkit. This innovative approach makes the subject more accessible and engaging to a broader audience, further promoting interest and understanding in quantum materials and their potential applications.

In conclusion, the research conducted in understanding and controlling electronic, magnetic, and structural interactions at interfaces between atomically-thin quantum materials has yielded significant breakthroughs with far-reaching implications. Not only does it open up possibilities for developing energy-efficient devices, but it also contributes to the advancement of various technologies in computation, information storage, and energy storage. Moreover, the project's commitment to training and mentoring students from diverse backgrounds ensures that the field of quantum materials continues to thrive with fresh perspectives and talent.
